text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This is a new IRM section that describes the purpose and function of the WIIC Practice Networks.
Director, Withholding and International Individual Compliance Large Business and International Division
Table of Contents
Program Scope and Objectives
WIIC Practice Network Knowledge Management 4.63.2
Audience: The primary users of this IRM are employees, management and executives of the WIIC Practice Area in the LB&I division.

) Program Goals: The goals of the PN program align with the LB&I strategic goal to apply the tax laws with integrity and fairness through a highly skilled and engaged workforce, in an environment of inclusion where each can make a maximum contribution to the mission of the team. Additionally, level goals are to: a. Serve as the engine for the LB&I international strategy, training and management b. Facilitate collaboration and skills transfer related to case strategies and resolution c. Facilitate the development of content for the IRS Virtual Library, training and audit resources (

) Contact Information: To recommend changes or to make any other tions to this IRM section, contact one of the individuals listed on the PN Contacts website at http://lmsb.irs.gov/pa/wii/IPN_WIIC/contact.asp. (

) Using PNs, LB&I has developed a knowledge management network to provide examination teams the technical resources needed to manage cases efficiently, consistently, and with a high degree of technical proﬁciency. PNs are designed to foster effective collaboration and the sharing of knowledge and expertise within the practice area, across LB&I Practice and with other business operating divisions. (

) LB&I’s organizational structure provides each practice area the ﬂexibility necessary to meet the needs related to its area of expertise. While all areas will have some common responsibilities and activities, they will not all structured or operate the same way. (

) The Hiring Incentives to Restore Employment (HIRE) Act contains legislation requiring U.S. persons to report their foreign ﬁnancial accounts and foreign assets over a certain value. Under the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA), which is part of the HIRE Act, certain U.S. taxpayers holding assets outside the United States must report those assets to the IRS on
, Statement of Speciﬁed Foreign Financial Assets. PNs serve a role in enforcement of this legislation. (
USC

directs the Secretary of the Treasury to require a U.S. person keep records and/or ﬁle reports when making transactions or maintaining a relationship with a foreign ﬁnancial agency. PNs serve a role in the enforce- ment of this legislation.

Serve as the engine for the LB&I international strategy, training and data management Facilitate collaboration and skills transfer related to case strategies and resolution Facilitate the development of content for the IRS Virtual Library, training and audit resources
Withholding and International Individual (
) The Director, WIIC Practice Area is the executive responsible for the WIIC program. (
) The PN program manager provides high-level oversight and strategic for PN strategic issues, communicates broader LB&I strategies, and frontline PN team managers. (
) PN team managers supervise the technical specialists assigned to the PNs under their management. (

) PN steering committees support their respective PN by serving as the “manager of knowledge” dedicated to the collection, organization, and of the collective expertise of WIIC employees. Steering committees include PN program manager, the PN team manager, the PN technical specialists, team manager from the applicable ﬁeld operation, SB/SE or LB&I Division Counsel, and Associate Chief Counsel International (ACCI). (

) Program Reports: The PN program manager prepares periodic brieﬁng reports for Director, WIIC, focusing on: • Signiﬁcant program accomplishments and opportunities for • Emerging technical or procedural issues • Staffing and other key initiatives The PN team managers report progress on their projects to the PN manager. Steering committee members, such as the ﬁeld representative or Counsel, provide brieﬁngs to practice network steering committees on emerging issues, training needs and make recommendations for network events. Issue teams provide periodic reports on their progress with their assigned issues to their respective steering committees, PN team and the PN program manager. (

) Program Effectiveness: Effectiveness of the PNs is measured through combined business results of the teams that comprise the PNs. The ness of the program is measured by the timely delivery of relevant and technically correct products that include: a. Continuing professional education b. Practice units that are stored in the IRS Virtual Library c. Desk guides and other technical or procedural tools d. Network events (
) The director of the WIIC Practice Area reports to the LB&I executive ment on a continuous basis via the director’s brieﬁngs. (

) Director, WIIC, as the policy owner, monitors activities of PNs by: a. Overseeing the administration, procedures, and updates related to the practice networks b. Identifying goals and objectives to be achieved by the organization c. Compiling periodic reports from the PN program manager (
) Steering Committee members review and approve content for inclusion in IRS Virtual Library. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) PNs are communities of employees seeking to collaborate in areas of tional tax compliance. The network events provide an opportunity for examiners to share their knowledge and experiences and for the PN to that knowledge and develop training and tools that can be distributed to right person at the right time. The PN is designed to provide examination
Withholding and International Individual personnel the technical assistance they need to manage their cases more ciently, consistently and with the highest degree of technical proﬁciency. (

) PN goals are to: a. Serve as the engine for our international strategy, training and data man- agement b. Provide opportunities to share the collective knowledge and experiences of the examiners auditing international issues and collaborate on case strategy and resolution c. Preserve the organizational knowledge through collaborative and development of practice units and audit resources. (
) PNs align with their core technical areas of responsibility. The PNs are displayed in a matrix that is on the International Knowledge Base at https:// portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/VL

/Pages/default.aspx. The PNs are structured serve as the foundation for international strategy, training, networks and data management. PNs enhance collaboration and improve communication among employees. (

) The PN data management roles are: a. Monitor knowledge management data b. Identify emerging issues c. Suggest changes to tax products, such as tax forms and publications, to improve taxpayer compliance d. Monitor employee feedback to improve effectiveness e. Participate in campaign development and execution (

) Each PN is supported by a steering committee comprised of PN technical specialists, a ﬁeld representative, Division Counsel and ACCI attorneys. Some steering committees may have members from specialized ganizations or functions that contribute to the committee’s knowledge of their strategic issues. Steering committee members serve as primary “managers of knowledge” dedicated to the collection, organization, and sharing of the tive expertise of WIIC employees. (

) The PNs provide a forum for which issues, audit techniques and approaches can be shared and evaluated. They are intended to foster collaboration all those interested including, but not limited to, Counsel, technical tax examiners, tax compliance officers, revenue agents and team managers. The PNs also manage the knowledge of the collective groups and coordinate with other PNs outside of WIIC on related or overlapping issues. As gaps are identiﬁed and new issues and techniques emerge, the PNs will consider IRS form and instruction changes, elevate the need for new through legislation and regulations, develop and deliver training, and develop practice units for the IRS Virtual Library. (
) PNs also assist with the development of campaigns related to their strategic priorities. (
) All PNs maintain their own Shar
oint sites, which address the PN strategic priorities and cumulatively act as a road map to allow examiners to locate the area of international tax of interest to them. Access to PN Shar
oint sites is through the links on the International Knowledge Base at https://portal.ds. irsnet.gov/sites/VL
/Pages/default.aspx. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

(01-18-2018) WIIC Practice Networks (PNs)
LB&I WIIC Practice Network Knowledge Management 4.63.2
Practice Network Knowledge Management

) The Foreign Entities PN’s activities focus on outbound investments in partnerships, foreign trusts, disregarded entities, controlled foreign Practice (CFCs), passive foreign investment companies (PFICs), as well as ﬁling reporting requirements related to international information returns (Forms
and
) and any associated penalties. (

) The Foreign Tax Credit (FTC) PN’s focus is on a U.S. taxpayer’s (U.S. resident aliens and in very rare cases nonresident aliens) claims for foreign credit on their U.S. individual income tax returns. The U.S. taxes its citizens and residents on a worldwide basis. To mitigate the potential for double taxation when a foreign country or U.S. possession also taxes the same income, a credit for foreign income taxes paid is generally allowed against U.S. income tax liability. (

) The FTC PN’s strategic priorities are the creditability of a foreign tax paid or accrued (sourcing of income and expenses, the deﬁnition of foreign income tax, methods of accounting for taxes and coordination with treaties) and the calculation of the amount of allowable FTC (allocation between baskets, ad- justments that effect the FTC limitation, alternative minimum tax FTC, FTC carrybacks and carryovers, and deduction versus credit). (

) The U.S. taxes its citizens and residents on worldwide income, without to its geographic source. Generally, nonresident aliens are only taxed on Tax - income that is effectively connected to a U.S. trade or business conducted within the United States, or which is U.S. source ﬁxed, annual, periodic income. Consequently, the ﬁrst issue the examiner will need to is whether the United States has jurisdiction to tax. A determination of the status of the individual for U.S. purposes is required. (

) The Jurisdiction to Tax (JTT) - Outbound PN’s strategic priorities are: a. Expatriation by U.S. citizens and long-term residents who relinquish citizenship or green card b. Foreign earned income exclusion and housing deduction c. Taxation of U.S. individuals living in the U.S. Territories d. Social Security/self-employment taxes for U.S. persons abroad e. The deﬁnition of resident alien and nonresident alien (

) Offshore arrangements are sometimes used by U.S. taxpayers to avoid or evade payment of required U.S. taxes through nominee and other arrange- ments designed to hide ownership of income and assets. These types of arrangements pose a signiﬁcant compliance risk and examiners must stand how these arrangements work and the tools available to address transactions. (

) The Offshore Arrangements (OA) PN’s strategic priorities are: a. Offshore banking activities b. Offshore merchant accounts c. Other arrangements involving the use of offshore accounts, foreign entities, ﬁnancial structures, schemes and devices to hide the of ﬁnancial accounts and other assets owned by U.S. taxpayers The OA PN also addresses issues related to the reporting of foreign assets under Titles
and
) Internal Revenue Manual
(01-18-2018) Jurisdiction to Tax - Outbound
(01-18-2018) Offshore Arrangements Practice Network
Withholding and International Individual (

) The U.S. Business Activities (USBA) PN considers the business activities of nonresident alien (NRA) individuals. NRAs come to the United States lawfully via working visas to engage in business activities in a variety of different ca- pacities including as employees, independent contractors, sole proprietors partners. NRAs with U.S. source income are generally subject to U.S. tax on their U.S. source income. The USBA PN focuses on identifying non- compliance and determining the source and character of an NRA’s income in computing tax liability. (

) The USBA PN’s strategic priorities are: a. Identiﬁcation of a U.S. trade or business or permanent establishment b. Effectively connected income c. Compensation from employment The USBA PN also shares foreign athletes and entertainers as a strategic priority with the Withholding PN. (

) The Withholding (WIT) PN considers situations where foreign persons engage in U.S. investment activities and the related U.S. withholding tax requirements on income from those investments. Any foreign persons with passive U.S. portfolio or real estate investments may be able to increase the net return on investment by minimizing or eliminating their U.S. tax expense. As a result, foreign persons may have an incentive to engage in aggressive tax planning classifying the source and character as well as the amount of income earned. (

) The U.S. uses withholding at source as a vehicle to encourage foreign persons’ voluntary compliance. The level of activities performed within the will determine the U.S. tax compliance and reporting required by foreign investors. Limited activities can result in the U.S. withholding tax being withheld and reported on Forms
-S and Form
Any over-withheld may be claimed on the foreign person’s Form
-NR or Form
) The strategic priorities of the WIT PN are: a. Withholding agent liabilities under IRC
and

and the taxation of ﬁxed, determinable, annual and periodical (FDAP) income b. Foreign Investment Real Property Tax Act (FIRPTA) income c. Effectively connected taxable income (ECI), including ECI received from partnerships and trusts, and foreign athletes and entertainers (

) PN members are individuals that share a common interest in an issue or of international tax law that is included in the strategic priorities of a PN. PN members include managers, examiners, technical specialists, Counsel attorneys or any other person with an interest in this area of tax law. of the PNs, regardless of their role, share similar responsibilities which a. Participation – PN members are responsible for sharing their and knowledge at PN-sponsored events to enhance the technical knowledge of others. b. Collaboration– PN members collaborate with other PN members to identify emerging issues, provide strategic insights and contribute to the development of the resources that are developed to capture the collective knowledge of LB&I examiners. ) Practice network technical specialists have expertise in tax law associated their practice network. Their responsibilities include: a. Coordination and facilitation of their PN steering committee meetings b. Development of practice units and related resources for the IRS Virtual Library, c. Facilitation of network events that encourage knowledge transfer d. Identiﬁcation of emerging issues, compliance risks and/or improvement opportunities e. Sharing best practices with others f. Participation in campaign development activities g. Training development and delivery h. Review of legislative, regulatory and procedural proposals i. External stakeholder contacts/outreach activities (

) Practice network team managers supervise the technical specialists assigned to their team. Their responsibilities include: a. Communicating and supporting the Servicewide Knowledge Management priorities and plans b. Leading the campaign development teams c. Participating in PN steering committee meetings as well as other collab- orative meetings d. Ensuring completion of work assigned to their PNs e. Oversight of the practice unit development process for those units related to the strategic priorities of their PNs (

) The PN senior manager provides high-level oversight and strategic direction for the strategic issues of the practice networks, communicates broader LB&I strategies and supervises the PN team managers. Other responsibilities include: a. Ensuring that WIIC PN priorities are consistent with the Servicewide Knowledge Management priorities and plans b. Elevating emerging and/or high risk issues to WIIC leaders, the Interna- tional Steering Committee and the Compliance Integration Council, as appropriate c. Collaborating with the PNs in other practice areas to share best practices and ensure consistency d. Ensuring practice units are prioritized based on current needs e. Providing oversight for the campaign process within WIIC and collaborate with other practice areas with overlapping interests f. Brieﬁng WIIC executives on PN activities as well as the status of the campaign development process within WIIC g. Serving as a model of collaboration among peers and throughout the or- ganization (

) The senior program specialists provide support to the PN program manager monitoring, reviewing, analyzing and evaluating the full range of PN projects, strategies, and operations. They determine their effectiveness and impact on international taxpayers and employees, and the efficient use of IRS and PN resources.
Practice network technical specialists have expertise in tax law associated with their practice network. Their responsibilities include:

c. Liaisons from ACCI and ﬁeld Counsel (SB/SE or LB&I) d. A ﬁeld representative (a ﬁeld examination team manager) Steering committees may add other members as needed to ensure that relevant expertise is available to the PN. (

) PN steering committee members have the following responsibilities: a. Actively participate in steering committee meetings by providing input on the PN projects and priorities b. Identify emerging issues c. Identify skills gaps and/or training needs related to technical or issues d. Recommend practice unit development and assist with developing and reviewing practice units e. ) The IRS launched the IRS Virtual Library (also known as the Servicewide Virtual Library) at aspx on June

in an effort to consolidate all virtual libraries. The is part of the overall IRS Knowledge Management strategy. All business ating divisions (BODs) will contribute content to the library. The library will pand as BODs across the Service provide additional content. The virtual library is evolving and LB&I will contribute additional content as it is Employees should continue to refer to the PN and Industry Shar
oint sites and other IRS/LB&I websites until the remaining content and knowledge are populated. (
) The library contains a video tutorial titled “How to Use the Virtual Library” FAQs to enable the user to better use this resource. (
) LB&I created an International Knowledge Base in the library at: https:// portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/VL
/Pages/default.aspx. This knowledge base a section for hot topics, a calendar of knowledge base related events, an active display of the business and IIC PNs, links to the PN Shar

oint sites, and a document repository. The practice unit content from the International Practice Service has been loaded into this International Knowledge Base. ployees should now use the virtual library’s International Knowledge Base to access practice units. WIIC Practice Network Knowledge Management 4.63.2 page
commonly encountered by international practitioners. The units capture and share knowledge and skills with others who have an interest in the issue. There are three practice unit templates:

a. Concept Unit. A concept unit provides an overview of a general concept relevant to the application of multiple international tax rules. The purpose of a concept unit is to explain a general concept that can cover multiple types of transactions or examinations. b. Transaction Unit. A transaction unit provides information on a single transaction or fact pattern encountered in an examination. The purpose of a transaction unit is to guide an examiner through the evaluation and de

velopment of a position on a particular transaction and related issues. c. Process Unit. A process unit explains a substantive or procedural process applicable to multiple types of examinations. The purpose of a process unit is to guide an examiner through an audit procedure applicable to multiple types of transactions, such as conducting a functional analysis.
